**The Relevance of Security in IAM Sector**

‌Fundamentally,‌ ‌we&#39;re‌ ‌living‌ ‌in‌ ‌a‌ ‌far‌ ‌more‌ ‌technologically-advanced‌ world‌ ‌than‌ we‌ ‌were‌ ‌a‌ ‌decade‌ ‌ago.‌ We‌ ‌are‌ ‌moving‌ ‌into‌ ‌a‌ ‌technical‌ ‌era‌ ‌briskly,‌ ‌and‌ ‌with‌ ‌this‌ ‌ever-evolving‌ ‌technology,‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌of utmost‌ ‌importance‌ ‌for‌ ‌every‌ ‌sector‌ ‌to‌ ‌buck‌ ‌up‌ ‌their‌ ‌security‌ ‌game.‌ ‌One‌ ‌‌ ‌such‌ ‌sector‌ ‌is‌ ‌IAM‌ ‌which‌ ‌is‌ ‌also‌ ‌known‌ ‌as‌ ‌Identity‌ ‌Access‌ ‌Management.‌ ‌

Traditionally‌, ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌a‌ ‌‌technology‌ ‌for‌ ‌ensuring‌ ‌that‌ ‌the‌ ‌people‌ ‌in‌ ‌an‌ ‌enterprise‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌appropriate‌ ‌access‌ ‌to‌ ‌technology‌ ‌resources.‌ ‌Previously‌ ‌it‌ ‌was‌ ‌also‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌streamline‌ ‌employee‌ ‌provisioning,‌ ‌managing‌ ‌access‌ ‌rights,‌ ‌authentication‌ ‌and‌ ‌authorization,‌ ‌and‌ ‌for‌ ‌a‌ ‌great‌ ‌many‌ ‌security‌ ‌purposes.‌ ‌But‌ ‌Nowadays‌ ‌it‌ ‌is‌ ‌not‌ ‌the‌ ‌same‌ ‌as‌ ‌it‌ ‌used‌ ‌to‌ ‌be‌ ‌before,‌ ‌Many‌ ‌big‌ ‌business‌ ‌houses‌ ‌are‌ ‌adopting‌ ‌this‌ ‌technology‌ ‌to‌ ‌manage‌ ‌their‌ ‌customer‌ ‌data.‌ ‌ ‌

Unfortunately,‌ ‌Identity‌ ‌management‌ ‌systems‌ ‌don&#39;t‌ ‌have‌ ‌the‌ ‌right‌ ‌potential‌ ‌to‌ ‌manage‌ ‌and‌ ‌secure‌ ‌a‌ ‌huge‌ ‌amount‌ ‌of‌ ‌customer‌ ‌data‌ ‌without‌ ‌any‌ ‌relevant‌ ‌security‌ ‌aspect.‌ ‌ ‌This‌ ‌is‌ ‌where‌ ‌‌the **relevance‌ ‌of‌ ‌security‌** ‌in‌ ‌the IAM‌ ‌Sector‌‌ ‌comes‌ ‌into‌ ‌play.‌

As per recent news incidents and breaches, like facebook where Up to 50 million Facebook users were affected, Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey&#39;s account was hacked, also news like &quot;32.8 Million Twitter Credentials May Have Been Leaked&quot; was viral. Both accepted that hundreds of users inadvertently gave access to their data through third-party apps.

Here are the stats of security breaches incidents noticed.

 ![](data:image/*;base64,)

Source : [https://bit.ly/2qyM7A7](https://bit.ly/2qyM7A7)

It has been proven that cyber data breaches are tremendously impacting the customers&#39; confidence, for instance, 46% dip in profit of most cloud-based companies was seen after the occurrence of a major data breach incidents.

Moreover, the global average cost of a data breach in 2017 was USD 3.6 million. One of the three largest credit agencies in the U.S., Equifax, suffered a breach in 2017 that affected 143 million consumers. JP Morgan also witnessed data breach that affected financial information of 3500 customers.

IAM is critical to protecting sensitive enterprise systems, assets, and information from unauthorized access or use. An end-to-end IAM implementation will reduce the likelihood and impact of data breaches, and ensure that only legitimate, authenticated users have access. IAM is crucial to protect the following areas by only allowing authorized access:

1. Data and information: Sensitive customer, business, supplier, or other data, stored on local servers, in the cloud, or elsewhere.
2. Software and applications: Systems used by employees, customers, suppliers, partner businesses, and others.
3. Development, testing, staging, and operational platforms: All IT environments used for product and service development, launch, and operations.
4. Devices: Laptops, desktops, smartphones, tablets, IoT, and other devices.
5. Locations: Business locations including private office spaces, data centers, and secure locations.
6. Integrations: Data that is being transmitted, received, stored, or otherwise interacted with as it moves between different areas.

The global Identity and Access Management (IAM) market size was valued at USD 9.90 billion in 2018 and is expected to expand at a CAGR of 13.1% from 2019 to 2025. Increase spending on security solutions by government bodies and large-scale enterprises to curb identity theft and to adhere to regulatory compliance are the prominent factors expected to boost the growth.

Security within the IAM domain can be provided via a lot of ways like:

1. Role-Based Access-where users will be provided access to information based on roles assigned like financial data could not be accessed by employees.
2. MFA- Strong passwords are a must for securing enterprise data and networks, but that is not enough. Most breaches occur due to compromised authentication.

a.something you know: example – password

b. Something you possess: example -hardware token, OTP on the mobile device, security question, Google authenticator

c.Something you are: example – retina scan, fingerprint

1. RBA- where risk-based authentication could be detected via the change in city, country, IP and device.
2. Password
  1. Password Expiration- the password will expire after a set duration, to increase security.
  2. Common/Breached/Dictionary Password Protection- were globally analyzed common, breached, dictionary passwords are avoided, to decrease risk.

1. Session Management- securing multiple requests to a service from the same user or entity.
2. IP Restriction- where a specific IP could be blacklisted or whitelisted, secure the website accessibility.
3. Brute force lockout-attack is that if you take an infinite number of attempts to guess a password, where the hacker is bound to be right eventually.
4. Bot Protection-which automate the function to detect and block malicious user requests and allow the same as soon as its behavior turns good, requiring no manual interference.
5. Detect anomaly-Where a monitoring system that can detect the anomaly in behavior.
6. Encryption at rest and transit- where the data is stored in encrypted format in DB as well as while transits, so that even when breached, encryption will provide an extra layer of difficulty to reach to the correct data.
7. Hashed Password storage- Hashing performs a one-way transformation on a password, turning the password into another String, called the hashed password. &quot;One-way&quot; means that it is practically impossible to go the other way - to turn the hashed password back into the original password

Well, the Above data and stats are itself enough to utter the importance and relevance of security in IAM. Adding to this, IAM helps protect against security breaches be it any industry.

Identity and access management (IAM) is a structure of business processes, policies, and technologies. This helps the management in electronic or digital identities. With this IAM framework, IT managers can able to control user&#39;s access to critical information within their organizations. Furthermore, Identity and access management products provide role-based access control, which allows system managers to regulate access to systems or networks based on the roles of individual users within the enterprise. The core objective of IAM systems is one digital identity for each individual. Once that digital identity has been established, it must be maintained, modified and monitored throughout each operator.
